Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Creating High Performance Electrodes for Li-ion Batteries
Award.AbstractNarration:
Li-ion batteries have enabled tremendous breakthrough in applications but the need for advanced battery electrodes that can deliver high capacity and power continues to drive battery producer R&D efforts. The PI and his team have developed a low-cost, high-throughput self-assembly process to create diverse well-organized nanoparticle structures in the electrodes with electric field. In the fabrication of electrodes, the PI's research has demonstrated advanced battery electrodes with enhanced rate capability, high energy density, long cycling life, and reduced cost.

The technique proposed in this project will produce high performance batteries needed by electric vehicle and other applications, which will benefit the society by addressing global energy and environmental challenges. Translating the technique to commercial applications will not only create new jobs and contribute to the economy, but will also increase the US competence in the important area of Li-battery manufacturing.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Li-ion batteries have enabled tremendous breakthrough in applications but the need for advanced battery electrodes that can deliver high capacity and power continues to drive battery producer R&D efforts. Current electrodes are created using a slurry of randomly distributed particles of active material, conductive additive, and binder in a carrier solvent, where the random distribution is a major limiting factor. Organized distribution of nanoparticles provides superior properties including fast transport, enhanced surface reactivity, and improved structural integrity that can dramatically improve the battery performance. We have developed a low-cost, high-throughput self-assembly process to create diverse well-organized nanoparticle network structures in the electrodes with electric field, allowing advanced battery electrodes with enhanced rate capability, higher energy density, longer cycling life, and reduced cost.

This project translates electric field processing techniques and fundamentals of electrochemistry to Li-ion battery electrode manufacturing, and therefore bridges the technical gap between the fundamental research and commercial production of advanced Li-ion batteries. The fundamental science and technology associated with the controlled self-assembly of nanoparticle network structures has been explored to optimize and demonstrate the fabrication technique and products. In the commercial world, this electric field processing approach can help advance the current technologies for producing battery electrodes. This project also broadly contributes to the fundamental knowledge in the areas of self-assembly technologies for manufacturing new structures at small scale as well as fundamental understanding of the relation between microstructures and electrochemical processes, which can benefit a range of practical applications. The technique helps the production of high performance batteries that are highly needed by electric vehicle and other applications, which will benefit the society by addressing global energy and environmental challenges.
